standard_metadata.standard_description: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.

question.content: **Which of the following are factor pairs for $16$?**

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that can be multiplied to get a certain product.  In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\green{16}$.
The factor pairs for $\green{16}$ are:   - $1$ and $16$   - $2$ and $8$ - $4$ and $4$

question.content: **Which of the following are factor pairs for $66$?**

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that can be multiplied to get a certain product.  In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\green{66}$.
- $1 \times 66 = \green {66}$ - $2 \times 33 = \green{66}$ - $3 \times 22  = \green {66}$ - $4 \times 16= 64$ - $6 \times 11 = \green{66}$
The factor pairs for $\green{66}$ are:   - $1$ and $66$   - $2$ and $33$ - $3$ and $22$ - $6$ and $11$

The factor pairs for $\green{12}$ are:   - $1$ and $12$   - $2$ and $6$ - $3$ and $4$

question.content: A rectangle has an area of $20$ square centimeters.    **Which of the following could be the rectangle's length and width?**   (Area $=$ length $\times$ width)

hints.content: Area $=$ length $\times$ width  The area of the rectangle is $\purple{20}$ square centimeters. The length and width are a factor pair with a product of $\purple{20}$.
$1 \times 20 = \purple {20}$   [[☃ image 1]]  $2 \times 10 = \purple {20}$     [[☃ image 2]]  $4 \times 5 = \purple {20}$   [[☃ image 3]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle made up of 20 squares. Above the rectangle is the label 20 cm. Along one side of the rectangle is the label 1 cm.
An area model using a rectangle made up of 2 rows of 10 squares each. Above the rectangle is the label 10 cm. Along one side of the rectangle is the label 2 cm.
An area model using a rectangle made up of 4 rows of 5 squares each. Above the rectangle is the label 5 cm. Along one side of the rectangle is the label 4 cm.

hints.content: [[☃ image 1]]  $3 \times 8 = 24$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle made up of 3 rows of 8 squares each. Above the rectangle is the label 8 cm. Along one side of the rectangle is the label 3 cm.

hints.content: The following factor pairs could be the rectangle's length and width:  - $1\text{ cm}$ and $20\text{ cm}$ - $2\text{ cm}$ and $10\text{ cm}$ - $4\text{ cm}$ and $5\text{ cm}$

question.content: There are $56$ unicorns at magic camp.  The unicorns stay in large fenced-in fields.  Every unicorn is in a field, and each field has the same number of unicorns.  **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of fields| Unicorns per field :-: | :-:  $1$ | $56$ $2$ |   | $14$ $7$ |

hints.content: We know there are $\greenD{56 \text{ total unicorns}}$.  $\redD{\text{Number of fields}} \times \blueD{\text{ Number of unicorns per field}} = \greenD{\text{Total unicorns}}$
$\redD? \times\blueD{56} = \greenD{56}$   $\redD1 \times\blueD{56} = \greenD{56}$     If there is $\redD1$ field, there will be $\blueD{56}$ unicorns in the field.
$\redD2 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{56}$   $\redD2 \times\blueD{28} = \greenD{56}$     If there are $\redD2$ fields, there will be $\blueD{28}$ unicorns in each field.
$\redD? \times\blueD{14} = \greenD{56}$   $\redD4 \times\blueD{14} = \greenD{56}$     If there are $\redD4$ fields, there will be $\blueD{14}$ unicorns in each field.
$\redD? \times\blueD8 = \greenD{56}$   $\redD7 \times\blueD{8} = \greenD{56}$     If there are $\redD7$ fields, there will be $\blueD{8}$ unicorns in each field.
Here is the completed table:  Number of fields| Unicorns per field :-: | :-:  $1$ | $56$ $2$ | $28$ $4$ | $14$ $7$ |  $8$

question.content: Blanca has $32$ marbles.  She wants to put her marbles into bags so each bag has the same number of marbles and no marbles are left over.   **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of Bags | Marbles per bag :-: | :-:  $1$ |    | $16$ $4$ |

hints.content: We know there are $\greenD{32 \text{ total marbles}}$.  $\redD{\text{number of bags}} \times \blueD{\text{ number of marbles per bag}} = \greenD{\text{total marbles}}$
$\redD1 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{32}$   $\redD1 \times\blueD{32} = \greenD{32}$    If Blanca uses $\redD1$ bag, there will be $\blueD{32}$ marbles in the bag.
$\redD?  \times\blueD{16} = \greenD{32}$   $\redD2 \times\blueD{16} = \greenD{32}$     If Blanca uses $\redD2$ bags, there will be $\blueD{16}$ marbles in each bag.
$\redD4 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{32}$   $\redD4 \times\blueD{8} = \greenD{32}$     If Blanca uses $\redD4$ bags, there will be $\blueD8$ marbles in each bag.
Here is the completed table:  Number of Bags | Marbles per bag :-: | :-: | :-: $1$ |  $32$ $2$ | $16$ $4$ |  $8$

question.content: $40$ students are going on a field trip to the aquarium.  Every student needs to be in a group, and all groups must have the same number of students.  **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of groups | Students per group :-: | :-:   | $40$ $2$ |   | $10$

hints.content: We know there are $\greenD{40 \text{ total students}}$.  $\redD{\text{Number of groups}} \times \blueD{\text{ Number of students per group}} = \greenD{\text{Total students}}$
$\redD? \times\blueD{40} = \greenD{40}$   $\redD1 \times\blueD{40} = \greenD{40}$     If there is $\redD1$ group, there will be $\blueD{40}$ students in the group.
$\redD2  \times{}\blueD{?} = \greenD{40}$   $\redD2 \times\blueD{20} = \greenD{40}$     If there are $\redD2$  groups, there will be $\blueD{20}$ students in each group.
$\redD? \times\blueD{10} = \greenD{40}$   $\redD4 \times\blueD{10} = \greenD{40}$     If there are $\redD4$  groups, there will be $\blueD{10}$ students in each group.
Here is the completed table:  Number of groups | Students per group - | - | - $1$| $40$ $2$ | $20$ $4$ | $10$

question.content: A group of $24$ friends is making teams to play tag.  Every player must be on a team, and each team must have the same number of players.    **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of teams | Players per team :-: | :-:  $1$ | $24$ $2$ |   | $8$ $4$ |

hints.content: We know there are $\greenD{24 \text{ total players}}$.  $\redD{\text{Number of teams}} \times \blueD{\text{ Number of players per team}} = \greenD{\text{Total players}}$
$\redD2  \times{} \blueD{?} = \greenD{24}$   $\redD2 \times \blueD{12} = \greenD{24}$     If there are $\redD2$ teams, there will be $\blueD{12}$ players on each team.
$\redD? \times\blueD{8} = \greenD{24}$   $\redD3 \times\blueD{8} = \greenD{24}$     If there are $\redD3$  teams, there will be $\blueD{8}$ players on each team.
$\redD4 \times{}\blueD{?} = \greenD{24}$   $\redD4 \times\blueD{6} = \greenD{24}$     If there are $\redD4$ teams, there will be $\blueD{6}$ players on each team.
Here is the completed table:  Number of teams | Players per team :-: | :-:  $1$ | $24$ $2$ | $12$ $3$| $8$ $4$ | $6$

question.content: Tyler is cleaning up his $36$ toy cars.  He wants to put every car in a toy bin, and he wants each bin to have the same number of cars.  **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of bins | Cars per bin :-: | :-:  $1$ | $36$ $2$ |   | $12$ $4$ |  $6$ | $6$

hints.content: We know there are $\green{36 \text{ total cars}}$.  $\redD{\text{Number of bins}} \times \blueD{\text{ Number of cars per bin}} = \greenD{\text{Total number of cars}}$
$\redD2 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{36}$   $\redD2 \times\blueD{18} = \greenD{36}$     If there are $\redD2$ bins, there will be $\blueD{18}$ cars in each bin.
$\redD? \times\blueD{12} = \greenD{36}$   $\redD3 \times\blueD{12} = \greenD{36}$     If there are $\redD3$ bins, there will be $\blueD{12}$ cars in each bin.
$\redD4 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{36}$   $\redD4 \times\blueD{9} = \greenD{36}$     If there are $\redD4$ bins, there will be $\blueD{9}$ cars in each bin.
Here is the completed table:  Number of bins | Cars per bin :-: | :-:  $1$ | $36$ $2$ | $18$ $3$ | $12$ $4$ | $9$ $6$ | $6$

question.content: Davi has $75$ flower seeds.  He wants to plant the seeds in pots so that every seed is planted, and every pot has the same number of seeds.    **Use what you know about factor pairs to complete the table.**  Number of pots | Seeds per pot :-: | :-:    | $75$ $3$ |     | $15$

hints.content: We know there are $\greenD{75 \text{ total seeds}}$.  $\redD{\text{Number of pots}} \times \blueD{\text{ Number of seeds per pot}} = \greenD{\text{Total number of seeds}}$
$\redD? \times\blueD{75} = \greenD{75}$   $\redD1 \times\blueD{75} = \greenD{75}$     If there is $\redD1$ pot, there will be $\blueD{75}$ seeds in the pot.
$\redD3 \times{}\blueD? = \greenD{75}$   $\redD3 \times\blueD{25} = \greenD{75}$     If there are $\redD3$ pots, there will be $\blueD{25}$ seeds in each pot.
$\redD? \times\blueD{15} = \greenD{75}$   $\redD5 \times\blueD{15} = \greenD{75}$     If there are $\redD5$ pots, there will be $\blueD{15}$ seeds in each pot.
Here is the completed table:  Number of pots | Seeds per pot :-: | :-:  $1$ | $75$ $3$ | $25$ $5$ | $15$

question.content: **Complete the table to find all the factor pairs of $88$.**  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and | $88$ $2$ | and |   | and | $22$  | and | $11$

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that we can multiply to get a certain product.

In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\greenE{88}$.    $\begin{align} 1 \times 88 &= \greenE{88}\\\\ 2 \times 44 &= \greenE{88}\\\\ 4 \times 22 &= \greenE{88}\\\\ 8 \times 11 &= \greenE{88} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and | $88$ $2$ | and | $\blueE{44}$ $\blueE{4}$ | and | $22$ $\blueE{8}$ | and | $11$

question.content: **Complete the table to find all the factor pairs of $30$.**  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-:  | and | $30$ $2$ | and | $15$ $3$ | and |   | and | $6$

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that we can multiply to get a certain product.

In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\greenE{30}$.    $\begin{align} 1 \times 30 &= \greenE{30}\\\\ 2 \times 15 &= \greenE{30}\\\\ 3 \times 10 &= \greenE{30}\\\\ 5 \times 6 &= \greenE{30} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $\blueE{1}$ | and | $30$ $2$ | and | $15$ $3$ | and | $\blueE{10}$ $\blueE{5}$ | and | $6$

question.content: **Complete the table to find all the factor pairs of $45$.**  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and |   | and | $15$ $5$ | and |

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that we can multiply to get a certain product.
In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\greenE{45}$.    $\begin{align} 1 \times 45 &= \greenE{45}\\\\ 3 \times 15 &= \greenE{45}\\\\ 5 \times 9 &= \greenE{45} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and | $\blueE{45}$ $\blueE{3}$ | and | $15$ $5$ | and | $\blueE{9}$

question.content: **Complete the table to find all the factor pairs of $42$.**  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and | $42$ $2$ | and |   | and | $14$ $6$ | and |

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that we can multiply to get a certain product.

In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\greenE{42}$.    $\begin{align} 1 \times 42 &= \greenE{42}\\\\ 2 \times 21 &= \greenE{42}\\\\ 3 \times 14 &= \greenE{42}\\\\ 6 \times 7 &= \greenE{42} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $1$ | and | $42$ $2$ | and | $\blueE{21}$ $\blueE{3}$ | and | $14$ $6$ | and | $\blueE{7}$

question.content: **Complete the table to find all the factor pairs of $50$.**  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-:  | and | $50$  | and | $25$ $5$ | and |

hints.content: A factor pair is $2$ whole numbers that we can multiply to get a certain product.
In this case, we are looking for pairs that have a product of $\greenE{50}$.    $\begin{align} 1 \times 50 &= \greenE{50}\\\\ 2 \times 25 &= \greenE{50}\\\\ 5 \times 10 &= \greenE{50} \end{align}$
Here is the completed table:  First factor | | Second factor :-: | - | :-: $\blueE{1}$ | and | $50$ $\blueE{2}$ | and | $25$ $5$ | and | $\blueE{10}$
